article.title: Optimal Densification for Fast and Accurate Minwise Hashing

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following best describes the key difference between "Densification" and "Improved Densification" in Figure 1?
choices: Densification uses a single pass over the data, while Improved Densification requires two passes.
Densification assigns values from the nearest right non-empty bin, while Improved Densification randomly chooses between left and right.
Densification does not use random bits, while Improved Densification utilizes them for value assignment.
Densification always results in identical hash values for S1 and S2, while Improved Densification does not.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main issue illustrated in Figure 2 regarding load balancing in existing densification strategies?
choices: Re-assignment of bins is not performed, leaving many bins empty.
Re-assignment is biased towards utilizing information from only the closest non-empty bin.
Re-assignment fails to maintain consistency across different sets S1 and S2.
Re-assignment completely ignores information from non-empty bins.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation (12) represents the probability of collision for the proposed optimal densification scheme (h*). What does this equation tell us about the relationship between h* and the actual Jaccard similarity (R)?
choices: The collision probability under h* is significantly different from the actual Jaccard similarity.
The collision probability under h* is an unbiased estimator of the actual Jaccard similarity.
The collision probability under h* is always lower than the actual Jaccard similarity.
The collision probability under h* is only an accurate estimator for dense datasets.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the role of the "attempt" variable in Algorithm 1?
choices: To track the total number of empty bins encountered.
To ensure that the algorithm terminates even if cycles occur during re-assignment.
To limit the maximum number of iterations allowed for finding a non-empty bin.
To store the hash values of previously processed bins.
